A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease is admitted to the ICU following a myocardial infarction (MI). He develops profound hypotension (BP: 78/52 mmHg) and bradycardia (HR: 40 bpm) despite adequate fluid resuscitation. ECG shows sinus bradycardia without any evidence of heart block. His medications include metoprolol, aspirin, atorvastatin, and ramipril. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient’s hypotensive crisis?

A 58-year-old female with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents to the emergency department with episodes of syncope and palpitations. She was recently started on a new antiarrhythmic medication for her arrhythmia. On examination: BP: 110/70 mmHg, HR: 80 bpm (irregular) ECG- Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Not the Other Options? Amiodarone → Prolongs QT, but rarely causes TdP because it also has sodium channel blocking properties, stabilizing repolarization. Lidocaine → A Class Ib antiarrhythmic, it shortens QT interval and does not cause TdP. Quinidine → A Class Ia antiarrhythmic, also prolongs QT and increases TdP risk, but Ibutilide has the highest risk among the given options.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of focal epilepsy with secondary generalization presents to the neurology clinic for follow-up. He reports weight gain and mild tremors over the past few months. His medication history includes a recently initiated antiepileptic drug (AED), is known to inhibit the GABA transaminase enzyme as part of its mechanism of action. On neurological examination, there are no focal deficits, but the patient exhibits mild postural tremor. Laboratory Findings: • Liver enzymes (ALT, AST): Mildly elevated • Ammonia level: Borderline high Which of the following antiepileptic drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's seizure control?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Not the Other Options? Tiagabine → Increases GABA by inhibiting its reuptake, not by inhibiting GABA transaminase. Levetiracetam → Modulates synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A), which affects neurotransmitter release but does not influence GABA metabolism. Lamotrigine → Works by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels and does not increase GABA levels

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of persistent asthma and allergic rhinitis presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of worsening nighttime symptoms, including frequent awakenings due to cough and wheezing. His symptoms have been poorly controlled despite regular use of an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) and a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA). He has no history of smoking or cardiac disease. Pulmonary function tests reveal an FEV1/FVC ratio of 68%, and fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) is elevated. His physician decides to add an oral agent that selectively targets a key inflammatory mediator involved in eosinophilic airway inflammation and bronchoconstriction. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate add-on therapy in this patient?
Which of the following drugs is useful in managing cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Not the Other Options? Acrolein –because acrolein is the actual toxic metabolite responsible for hemorrhagic cystitis. The goal is to neutralize it with Mesna, not administer it.
  • • Oprelvekin is a recombinant IL-11 analog used to manage chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia by stimulating platelet production. It has no role in preventing or treating hemorrhagic cystitis. Dexrazoxane is used to prevent doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity by reducing oxidative damage in the heart. It does not protect against hemorrhagic cystitis

questions.text: Which anticoagulant does not require routine monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Not the Other Options? Warfarin – Requires regular INR monitoring due to variable metabolism, drug interactions, and dietary influences (vitamin K intake). Therapeutic range (INR 2-3) is crucial to balance efficacy and bleeding risk. Lepirudin – A direct thrombin inhibitor used in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Requires aPTT (activated partial thromboplastin time) monitoring to adjust the dose and prevent bleeding. Enoxaparin – A low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) that generally does not require routine monitoring in most patients. However, in renal impairment (CrCl <30 mL/min), obesity, or pregnancy, anti-Xa level monitoring may be needed

questions.text: A 32-year-old industrial worker is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a suspected chemical exposure in a factory dealing with plastics and metal processing. His coworkers report that he suddenly collapsed while working near a cyanide-containing solution. On examination: Vital signs: BP 85/60 mmHg, HR 110/min, RR 30/min, Skin: Flushed, no cyanosis, ABG: Metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap, Pulse oximetry: Shows normal oxygen saturation despite severe distress, Blood gas: Lactic acidosis (high lactate levels). The most appropriate antidote to administer in this case is:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Not the Other Options? Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) – This patient has metabolic acidosis, but bicarbonate does not directly neutralize cyanide. While it may help correct acidosis, it does not reverse cyanide toxicity. Atropine – Atropine is used for organophosphate poisoning (cholinergic toxicity), which presents with salivation, bradycardia, miosis, and respiratory distress. Cyanide poisoning causes metabolic acidosis, not cholinergic toxicity. Pralidoxime (2-PAM) – Pralidoxime is used in organophosphate poisoning to regenerate acetylcholinesterase. It has no role in cyanide poisoning, which affects mitochondrial respiration, not neurotransmitters

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody targets IL-6 receptors in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Not the Other Options? Rituximab – Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody that targets B cells, used in RA patients who fail TNF inhibitors or have severe seropositive RA. While effective, it does not target IL-6. Infliximab – Anti-TNF-α monoclonal antibody used in RA, ankylosing spondylitis, Crohn’s disease, and psoriasis. While TNF-α inhibitors are commonly used in RA, this question specifically asks for an IL-6 inhibitor. Eculizumab – Complement C5 inhibitor, used in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) and atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS). It has no role in rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: A 65-year-old ICU patient with a history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease (GFR 25 mL/min) is diagnosed with Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia and septic shock. His blood culture shows a multidrug-resistant (MDR) Pseudomonas strain, susceptible only to ceftolozane-tazobactam, colistin, and amikacin. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial empiric treatment in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why Not the Other Options? Colistin monotherapy – Colistin is nephrotoxic and neurotoxic, making it less favorable in a CKD patient. Should not be used as monotherapy due to the risk of developing resistance. Amikacin monotherapy – Aminoglycosides should never be used as monotherapy for Pseudomonas bacteremia due to poor lung penetration and nephrotoxicity. Piperacillin-tazobactam – The blood culture already showed resistance to most agents, and piperacillin-tazobactam was not among the susceptible drugs. Using an ineffective antibiotic delays appropriate therapy and worsens mortality in septic shock.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), stage 3 chronic kidney disease (GFR 45 mL/min), and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is on metformin and sitagliptin. His HbA1c is 8.3%, and he reports fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. Which of the following is the best next step in his diabetes management?

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with persistent otalgia that is unresponsive to standard otitis externa treatment. He also reports purulent otorrhea and new-onset difficulty swallowing. On examination, his external auditory canal is edematous with granulation tissue at the bony-cartilaginous junction. Cranial nerve examination reveals ipsilateral facial weakness and dysphagia. A CT scan shows erosion of the temporal bone and involvement of the skull base.Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate surgical debridement of the external ear canal

options.label: B
options.text: Topical antibiotic-steroid drops and routine follow-up

options.label: D
options.text: High-dose systemic corticosteroids to reduce inflammation

questions.correct_answer: C. Intravenous antibiotics and glycemic control

questions.text: During an exploratory tympanoplasty for chronic otitis media, a surgeon carefully dissects the epitympanic space. In the process, a small, sharp bony projection is identified near the head of the malleus. The surgeon notes that this structure seems to “guide” a tendon that curves medially and recalls its importance as a surgical landmark.Based on the clinical scenario, which of the following statement regarding bony projection is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It serves as the direct attachment site for the tensor tympani muscle, which originates from the malleus.

options.label: B
options.text: It acts as a pulley for the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle as it courses toward the medial wall of the tympanic cavity.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a variable structure found only in pediatric ears, typically regressing or fusing with adjacent ossicles in adulthood.

options.label: D
options.text: It forms the lateral boundary of the sinus tympani, thereby guiding surgical approaches to cholesteatoma removal.

questions.correct_answer: B. It acts as a pulley for the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle as it courses toward the medial wall of the tympanic cavity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with chronic bad breath (halitosis) and intermittent throat discomfort but denies frequent episodes of tonsillitis. On examination, small, firm, yellowish deposits are palpated within the tonsillar crypts. The patient is concerned about the persistent foul odor and occasional irritation.Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Tonsilloliths are incidental radiographic findings that rarely produce any symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Tonsilloliths are composed primarily of calcium salts and bacterial debris, which can contribute to halitosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Tonsilloliths are an early sign of malignant transformation in the tonsils and require urgent biopsy.

options.label: D
options.text: Tonsilloliths are exclusively seen in pediatric patients and tend to resolve spontaneously with age.

questions.correct_answer: B. Tonsilloliths are composed primarily of calcium salts and bacterial debris, which can contribute to halitosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of episodic vertigo lasting 20–90 minutes, often associated with a feeling of fullness in the affected ear, tinnitus (a roaring sound), and fluctuating hearing loss that initially affects low frequencies. The episodes are unpredictable, and she reports significant anxiety about when the next attack will occur. She has no history of ear infections or trauma.Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line management strategy for this patient’s condition?

options.label: B
options.text: High-dose systemic steroids for nerve inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: A low-sodium diet and diuretics to reduce endolymphatic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical decompression of the endolymphatic sac

questions.correct_answer: C. A low-sodium diet and diuretics to reduce endolymphatic pressure

questions.text: A 30-year-old male motorcyclist presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He complains of pain and swelling over the nasal bridge with difficulty breathing through the nose. On examination, there is bilateral nasal bone tenderness, periorbital swelling, and crepitus over the nasal dorsum. No cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak is noted. A lateral skull X-ray and CT scan confirm a linear fracture of the nasal bone without displacement.Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding this fracture?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an unstable fracture requiring immediate surgical fixation.

options.label: B
options.text: It commonly involves the maxilla and zygomatic bones.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a type of simple nasal bone fracture without major displacement.

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with a high risk of CSF rhinorrhea and intracranial injury

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a type of simple nasal bone fracture without major displacement.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of severe epistaxis. He reports that the bleeding is mostly unilateral, from the left nostril, and persists despite pinching the nose for 15 minutes. He denies trauma but has been taking aspirin and enalapril for years. On examination, his blood pressure is 175/95 mmHg, and active bleeding is seen in the posterior nasal cavity.Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic hepatitis C–associated cirrhosis presents to the emergency room with confusion and abdominal pain. He is noted to have ascites and asterixis. Which statement is true regarding care of this patients?

options.label: B
options.text: Endoscopic variceal sclerotherapy is the preferred option for secondary prophylaxis of variceal haemorrhage.

options.label: C
options.text: If Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score more than 10 consider liver transplant.

questions.correct_answer: A. Patients with ascites fluid total protein < 1 g/dL should receive prophylactic antibiotics as risk of SBP is high.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon in DM and choose the correct statement/s about it. 1. The picture shows Dawn phenomenon 2. It is due to excess night-time dose of Insulin 3. A 31 year old patient presented with 4 hypopigmented patches on back and 4 patches on forearm with loss of sensation. Treatment regimen would be?

options.label: A
options.text: Monthly rifampicin 600mg, clofazimine 300 mg. Daily dapsone 100mg, clofazimine 50 mg

options.label: B
options.text: Monthly rifampicin 450 mg, clofazimine 150 mg. Daily dapsone 50mg, clofazimine 50 mg on alternate day

options.label: C
options.text: Monthly rifampicin 450 mg, clofazimine 150 mg. Daily dapsone 50mg, clofazimine 50 mg

questions.correct_answer: A. Monthly rifampicin 600mg, clofazimine 300 mg. Daily dapsone 100mg, clofazimine 50 mg

A 26-year-old woman presents with a palpable thyroid nodule shown in the image and needle biopsy demonstrates amyloid in palpable lymph nodes on the same side as the lesion. The preferred treatment should be:

options.label: A
options.text: Removal of the involved node, the isthmus, and the enlarged lymph node.

options.label: B
options.text: Removal of the involved lobe, the isthmus, a portion of the opposite lobe, and the enlarged lymph node

options.label: C
options.text: Total thyroidectomy and neck dissection on the side of the enlarged lymph node

options.label: D
options.text: Total thyroidectomy and irradiation of the cervical lymph nodes

questions.correct_answer: C. Total thyroidectomy and neck dissection on the side of the enlarged lymph node

options.label: A
options.text: For laparotomy closure the length of suture should be 4 times the length incision length.

options.label: B
options.text: In GI anastomosis, Lembert suture refers seromuscular sutures

options.label: C
options.text: Non absorbable monofilament sutures are considered best.

questions.correct_answer: D. Intestinal anastomosis strength is provided by muscularis propria.

During laparotomy the structure shown in the picture was found incidentally in distal ileum. Which of the following is false about this condition

options.label: B
options.text: Ectopic gastric mucosa is found in 50% of cases

options.label: C
options.text: Meckle’s receives its blood supply from the vessel supplying adjoining ileum

options.label: D
options.text: Hernia containing Meckel’s is called Littre’s Hernia.

questions.correct_answer: C. Meckle’s receives its blood supply from the vessel supplying adjoining ileum

questions.text: Treatment of type IV Mirizzi syndrome is?

options.label: D
options.text: Cholecystectomy and Roux and Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.correct_answer: D. Cholecystectomy and Roux and Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: Predominantly Blood born metastasis is seen in which type of testicular tumour?

questions.correct_answer: D. 5% Dextrose solutions in free water

questions.text: Bone pearl’s or wax drippings is pathogonomic of which type of burn?

A 62 year old male patient presented with bleeding PR. Proctoscopy revealed a growth 4 cm above anal verge. Biopsy report came out as moderately differentiated Adenocarcinoma of rectum. After investigation the disease was staged as T2 N1. What should be the best treatment for this patient?
What is the sequence of instruments used while doing Laparoscopic cholecystectomy?

A young male patient sustained a right tibial shaft fracture following raod traffic accident. The Patient's right leg was immobilized with plaster cast. This patient now presents to the emergency with serve pain in the leg. On examination, the distal pulses are absent, on passive stretching the pain increases, and on opening the plaster, the right leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the most appropriate management in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: Opening of the plaster is sufficient

questions.text: A patient who had a history of fracture of his right leg came for a follow up appointment where his cast was removed for assessment. The doctor found that the area was deformable but not displaceable and thus he re-applied the cast. What stage of fracture healing is the patient likely to be in ?
Which of the following hip fractures is most likely to disrupt perfusion of the femoral head?
A 2-month old baby is lifted by her mother by holding the wrist of the child. The child started crying and was not moving her elbow. The most likely diagnosis is –
Which of the following is seen in osteoporosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Calcium normal and ALP normal

questions.text: Capnography is used during anesthesia to monitor:
Most common cause of admission after day care surgery:

An anesthetist is preparing to intubate a patient for emergency surgery. Rapid onset and short duration of action are essential. Which non-depolarizing muscle relaxant is best suited for this scenario?

A 34-year-old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The patient has a past medical history of asthma on regular treatment with last exacerbation a month back. Rest all investigations are normal. Standard induction is done with propofol and fentanyl with vecuronium as muscle relaxant and cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted and confirmed in position using a capnography trace on the monitor. Shortly after the commencement of the surgery, the ventilator suddenly start showing alarm of increased peak airway pressures and the capnography waveform changes to image A. the anaesthesiologist immediately identifies the problem and intervenes and after 10 mins the capnograph changes to image B. which of the following is true about the intervention by the anesthesiologist?

options.label: A
options.text: The anesthesiologist immediately changed the endotracheal tube with a larger tube

options.label: B
options.text: The anesthesiologist immediately deepened the plane of anesthesia by a bolus dose of propofol

options.label: C
options.text: The anesthesiologist changed the ventilator settings to higher tidal volume

options.label: D
options.text: The anesthesiologist informed the surgeon to stop the surgery

questions.correct_answer: B. The anesthesiologist immediately deepened the plane of anesthesia by a bolus dose of propofol

questions.text: A patient with a history of severe coagulopathy presents for emergency midline laparotomy surgery. Which of the following neuraxial anesthesia techniques is contraindicated in this patient?

A workup for cancer is negative, yet your patient refuses to accept the diagnosis and becomes increasingly anxious and expresses an intense sense of impending doom. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for the treatment of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common cause is gynaecological surgery

options.label: B
options.text: It causes continuous wetness of genitalia

options.label: C
options.text: Middle swab is blue in Methylene blue three swab test

options.label: D
options.text: Martius flap surgery is done for VVF

questions.correct_answer: A. The most common cause is gynaecological surgery

questions.text: A 23 years old girl has come to gynaecological OPD with symptom of yellowish-green, frothy and foul-smelling vaginal discharge with itching and on speculum examination there is redness of cervix and vagina. Which of the following is the likely cause?

A 33 years old G3P2L2 with twin gestation has 38 weeks of pregnancy. On examination, it was found that there was breech-cephalic presentation. USG revealed a thick septum between two babies creating a lambda sign. What is the correct line of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Wait and watch for normal labour

options.label: B
options.text: Do cesarean section whenever patient goes in spontaneous labour

options.label: D
options.text: Do cesarean section at 41 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 27 years old primigravida with 12 weeks of gestation has come to ANC OPD. She had undergone x-ray for wrist fracture which was caused by trauma. She is worried about the outcome of pregnancy. What should be the plan of action in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: Explain to her that there is a risk of leukaemia in the baby and do cordocentesis at 18 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Explain to her that there is a risk of cardiovascular anomaly and do fetal 2D echo at 22 weeks

questions.text: A 33 years old patient has achieved pregnancy by IVF cycle. On doing ultrasonographical examination it was found that there was one gestational sac in the uterus and other gestational sac of two centimetric size in the ampulla of the left fallopian tube. What is the best treatment modality in this case if beta hCG value is 3450 international unit per litre?
A 27 years old female has history of epilepsy since last five years. She is on valproate therapy. She also has eight weeks of pregnancy. What advice would you give?

options.label: B
options.text: Change to a safe anti-epileptic drug like levetiracetam

options.label: D
options.text: Continue the same drug, add folic acid 4mg/day and do anomaly scan as usual

questions.correct_answer: D. Continue the same drug, add folic acid 4mg/day and do anomaly scan as usual

questions.text: A 27 years old Rh negative primigravida has 22 weeks of gestation. Her partner's blood group is O positive and her ICT is negative. What should be the plan of action in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: Do cordocentesis to rule out fetal anemia

options.label: C
options.text: Give injection Anti-D at 28 weeks of gestation

questions.correct_answer: C. Give injection Anti-D at 28 weeks of gestation

A 33 years old primigravida with full-term gestation was in active labour. On PV examination, cervix was seven cm dilated and supra orbital ridges of the fetus were clearly felt. What should be the next line of management?

The child has been experiencing multiple clusters of spasms daily, which have proven resistant to initial treatments. The clinical team is considering specific medication options to manage this severe form of epilepsy. Which of the following is the drug of choice for treating hypsarrhythmia associated with infantile spasms?

The child's medical history reveals a diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency and growth delays. Genetic testing confirms the presence of a specific autosomal recessive disorder. Which of the following is an autosomal recessive disorder?
A baby has not passed urine on first day of life. What should be the next step?
questions.correct_answer: C. Continue breast feeds and observe

questions.text: A 4-day-old newborn is found to have a markedly elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level of 100 IU/ml on routine newborn screening. To confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause of this condition, additional investigations are required. Which of the following investigations should be performed to confirm congenital hypothyroidism and further evaluate the thyroid gland?
A 11 years old child had fever, joint pains, elevated ESR, CRP and prolonged PR interval on ECG. His heart evaluation was normal. How long should he receive benzathine penicillin prophylaxis?

options.label: A
options.text: 5 yrs or till 21 yrs of life

options.label: B
options.text: 5 yrs or till 40 yrs of life

options.label: C
options.text: 10 yrs or till 18 yrs of life

options.label: D
options.text: 10 yrs or till 40 yrs of life

questions.correct_answer: A. 5 yrs or till 21 yrs of life

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with a 5-day history of abdominal pain, which he describes as crampy and diffuse. The pain has been worsening and is now severe enough to interfere with his daily activities. In addition to abdominal pain, his parents have noticed that he has developed a rash on his legs and buttocks. On examination, the child has palpable purpura, primarily on the extensor surfaces of his legs and buttocks, along with some mild swelling in the same areas. The boy also reports intermittent joint pain, particularly in his knees and ankles, and has been feeling unusually fatigued. What would be the treatment of choice?

A 2-month-old female infant with poor feeding and failure to gain weight is seen for evaluation. She is fed 24 kcal/oz of appropriately prepared infant formula. She was born at 39 weeks’ gestation, and her birth weight was 3 kg. She failed her newborn hearing screening. She had one hospital admission with vomiting and diarrhea at 6 weeks after birth. Her weight is currently at the third percentile, and her height is at the fifth percentile. Her cardiac examination reveals no murmur, and her chest is clear to auscultation. The rest of her physical examination findings are unremarkable. Laboratory data are shown: Sodium 134 mEq/L (134 mmol/L) Potassium 3.2 mEq/L (3.2 mmol/L) Chloride 110 mEq/L (110 mmol/L) Bicarbonate 14 mEq/L (14 mmol/L) Blood urea nitrogen 10 mg/dL (3.6 mmol/L) Creatinine 0.2 mg/dL (18 μmol/L) Glucose 90 mg/dL (5.0 mmol/L) Urine pH 7.0 Specific gravity 1.015 Urinalysis with microscopy Normal Sodium 60 mEq/L (60 mmol/L) Potassium 10 mEq/L (10 mmol/L) Chloride 55 mEq/L (55 mmol/L) Of the following, the MOST likely diagnosis for this child is

A 2 years old child has proximal muscle weakness, and has frequent falls during running. He is unable to stand from squatting position. Following is his muscle biopsy image. Which of the following statement is true?

A 45-year-old patient who presents with ptosis and muscle weakness was found to improve on rest. She complains of dysphagia and has engorged veins on the thorax. Using the CT scan image below, what is the diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Small cell cancer of the cancer

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent Vomiting. The vomiting's were projectile and non-bilious. Identify the condition using the radiograph below?
